title: Live panel: Activism within Academia
content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Professors, graduate and undergraduate students from Lund University in Sweden share views and tips on activism within academia in the age of the climate and ecological emergency. All welcome to join via the link below. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"-- LIVE BROADCAST at 16:00 on Monday the 20th! -- "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"In light of the ongoing climate emergency and mass extinction, members of society are increasingly taking to public activism. In parallel, universities around the globe are urged to advance their sustainability commitments and take a leading role in the transition to a sustainable society. In this event, a panel of students and researchers will explore the concept of activism within academia. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"In the time of a global emergency, what can or should researchers and students do in order to bring about change - at their universities, in the lecture hall, and through their research and studies? What could activism within academia entail? Does it, can, or should it exist? If so, in what shape? "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Panel: Steven Curtis - PhD student, IIIEE Martin Jarenmark - Research engineer, Department of Geology Milan Loose - Master student, IIIEE Kimberly Nicholas - Associate Professor, LUCSUS Lisa Quartey - Bachelor student, Centre for Languages and Literature Josefine Sarkez - PhD student, Division of Ethnology "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Where? The panel discussion will be live-streamed in this event. You can also join us on Zoom: "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"https://lu-se.zoom.us/j/393993453. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Organizers: Josefine Henman and Wilhelm Wanecek, together with Intersection "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Event info/live streaming: "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"https://www.facebook.com/events/622095911855937/?active_tab=about"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":""}]}]

author: Ellie

title: Climate Change Social Photography
content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"wEarthWhile seeks to reconnect humanity back to Earth by addressing the issues facing the environment and, consequently, those in it. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Work in the humanities is a real path for change because political marketing doesn’t appeal to people’s emotions the way that art and stories do. And it seems like getting people to connect to their own humanity and feelings is essential to our ability to connect and have compassion for others. We don’t want to distract, overwhelm, or create burden by adding more to social media with the endless stories surrounding the social sphere; the intention is to replace the focus back on the faces of the change. We don’t expect to approach society as what we think we want them to think, but instead what we want them to do and let them form what they should do. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"This is an intergenerational fight. We don’t want to have reform that will end climate change and environmental struggles by 80%. We want 100% improvement. To humanize the lives of climate change. To put a face to its impacts. To shine a light on the mostly unseen. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Social photography … let there be light. WearthWhile embodies social photography to shine a light on stories that aren’t accessible to the public. Our aim is to create a tool that primes for a social reform or even a revolutionary movement. To be a part of that transition to fundamentally change how society views climate change and what is being done about it. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The photoblog platform establishes positive and progressive discussion; at the heart of that is to include and recognize that people have feelings, experiences, beliefs and inner conflicts that influence the way they perceive and assimilate information. The internet offers opportunities for greater transparency and public participation into our changing climate. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"WearthWhile is a photoblog [story platform] that gives back the voice to the people. The commitment through this organization is to put emphasis on the opinions, impacts and experiences of people dealing with climate change and environmental problems. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Narrative offers a powerful means to engage an audience and convey complex concepts. Stories employ the elements of successful narratives, including personalizing their story, drawing on emotions and expressing their opinions. Dialogue rather than a debate offers the means to identify common purpose and foster constructive, evidence-based discourse."}]}]

title: #ReturnToOffender campaign goes digital
content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Surfers Against Sewage's #ReturnToOffender campaign goes digital to track plastic pollution in Britain's public spaces and on beaches, and challenges manufacturers to do more to protect the environment. The images will then be shared on social media, using the hashtags; #ReturnToOffender and #SurfersAgainstSewage. The brands/manufacturers should be tagged to urge them not to abandon action on the plastic pollution crisis. title: Online screening: Carbon and Captivity by Oliver Ressler
content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Oliver Ressler's new film Carbon and Captivity is online from April 16 through May 31, 2020. The screening is presented by Entrée (est. 2009), \"an independent, non-profit gallery in Bergen, Norway, devoted to the commissioning and production of new work by local and international artists.\" "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Ressler (b.1970, Austria), \"a filmmaker and artist based in Vienna, who works on issues such as economics, democracy, global warming, forms of resistance, and social alternatives\" has completed 34 films. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The upcoming remote screening will tackle the issue of Carbon capture and storage (CCS) technology. In their curatorial statement, e-Flux Video and Film stated, \"The oil and gas should be left in the ground and a fully funded transition to a post-oil economy begun immediately, but the large-scale introduction of CCS would delay the necessary decarbonization, deepening our dependence on the fossil fuel industry. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The film’s title refers to humanity’s “captivity” within the logic of capitalism, which seems to carry extractivism onward to the point of no return.\""}]}]

title: Seed Paper India
content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Flower growers are distressed seeing their blooms going waste due to the impact of COVID-19. Bengaluru-based, Seed Paper India, that manufactures organic handmade paper is helping by manufacturing flower embedded handmade paper to help the flower industry. The idea is to mix various kinds of flower petals into the waste cotton cloth-pulp used to make the paper. Flower petal note books, diaries, book marks, letter pads, calendars, visiting cards, souvenirs and mementos will be created and part of the proceeds of this endeavour will go to the farmers."}]}]

title: HS2 construction pushes ahead despite national lockdown
content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Since the construction of the HS2 railway line began, there have been countless ecosystems irreparably damaged and habitats destroyed, with many vital environments still at risk of destruction. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The Warwickshire Wildlife Trust highlighted that across the area of Warwickshire, \"over 8.1 hectares of ancient woodland will be lost\" ("},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.warwickshirewildlifetrust.org.uk/saving-wildlife-and-wild-places/hs2-warwickshire-our-position-hs2","children":[{"text":"https://www.warwickshirewildlifetrust.org.uk/saving-wildlife-and-wild-places/hs2-warwickshire-our-position-hs2"}]},{"text":") as a result of the line. Protests against the line have continued since the beginning of the project, but have remained largely unheard by those in power. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Alongside the inevitable environmental destruction, calls for construction to cease are also economically based as the project has far exceeded its original budget. Despite this, Boris Johnson gave them the green light to continue even in the face of the national lockdown ("},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-52293055","children":[{"text":"https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-52293055"}]},{"text":"). "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Countless more wildlife, green spaces and ecosystems will suffer as a result of the HS2 line and undoubtedly, protests to protect the natural world that is being destroyed will continue. "}]}]

author: Florence

title: Langholm Moor Community Buyout
content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"LANGHOLM MOOR: COMMUNITY BUYOUT"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Supporting the south of Scotlands largest community land purchase. To manage Langholm Moor for ecological restoration and community regeneration."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The Langholm Initiative have launched their crowdfunding campaign as they attempt the largest community buyout in the south of Scotland, hoping to bring 10,500 acres (about 5,600 football pitches) into community ownership. To be successful we need to raise the full purchase price by the end of October 2020."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":""},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.gofundme.com/f/langholm-moor-buyout","children":[{"text":"https://www.gofundme.com/f/langholm-moor-buyout"}]},{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":""},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.gofundme.com/f/langholm-moor-buyout","children":[{"text":""}]},{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The project has received a great boost today (07/05/2020)  as the John Muir Trust has pledged £100,000 towards the purchase."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"This project has the potential to act as a blueprint for other communities to place the environment at the heart of the decisions they make."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The project has received widespread support from organisations such as the John Muir Trust, RSPB Scotland, The Woodland Trust, Borders Forest Trust and The Revive Coalition. In addition to this we have cross party political support for our plans, due to the positive goals relating to climate change, ecological restoration and community regeneration."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Locally over 20 organisations have written letters of support for the buyout."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Kevin Cumming, the Langholm Initiative’s project leader said: “Our community plans here have international significance. At a time of climate emergency we are committing to undertake direct climate action including peatland restoration, ancient woodland restoration, the creation of new native woodlands and increasing the diversity of wildlife here”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“At this critical stage we are asking for the help of the public. We know it is a lot to ask at a time like this but if people can support us by donating to this project we will be demonstrating a more positive future for our children.”"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"These ambitious plans will be taken forward with the creation of the new Tarras Valley Nature Reserve."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Our plans"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Over the past six months, a thorough feasibility study has been conducted by community land specialists Duncan MacPherson, Faye McLeod  & Willie McGhee, (a huge thank you to previous crowdfunding supporters for making this possible)."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"This has given us a vision for a bright future for Langholm moor,  a sustainable business plan for the  Langholm Initiative, and demonstrated real community and environmental benefits.  Our plans centre around creating the Tarras Valley Nature Reserve on the vast majority of the land. Here we will carry out positive climate action and provide a new focus for wildlife tourism and recreation in the south of Scotland.  On a smaller area of land nearest the town itself we will investigate appropriate small scale renewable energy (a single small turbine and a single small solar farm) and the development of a small eco-campsite. We will also investigate repurposing disused and dilapidated steadings for either small scale housing or modern business units, both of which are badly needed in Langholm (there have only been 6 new houses built in Langholm in the past 30 years)."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"This land also holds huge historical and cultural significance to local people who care passionately about its future. For over 250 years the community have marked the boundaries of the common land and this tradition still goes on today with the annual Common Riding celebration."}]}]
author: Kevin Cumming

title: Reverse Garbage saves 60 tonnes of resources from landfill each  year
content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Reverse Garbage is a not-for-profit creative reuse centre  in Sydney’s inner west. Our workshops in schools and at community events reach take the reuse messaging to 16,000 people each year."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"To find out more, please visit www.reversegarbage.org.au or follow us on Facebook or Instagram. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"“It’s one thing to read about habitat loss and development and another to be driving for 30-40 minutes through miles of orange groves just to get to a really small conservation site,” Chase Kimmel, of the Florida Museum of Natural History, said. “It puts into perspective how much habitat loss affects all the animals that live in this area.”"}]}]

title: Seaside Scavenge: turning trash into cash
content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Founded in New South Wales, Australia, this non-profit organisation hosts \"Spring into Scavenge\" events where people gather litter from beaches and receive tokens in exchange. These tokens can then be used to \"purchase\" clothes or other preloved items that have been donated by the community, or items donated by local businesses such as beer, ice-cream or coffee. The program was piloted in 7 communities around the world, including Australia, the UK and South Africa. In 2019, \"Roughly 500 Scavengers were activated to remove 630kg of trash and 5,000+ butts in just ONE month.\" More events will be hosted in 2020."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":""},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.seasidescavenge.org/programs","children":[{"text":"https://www.seasidescavenge.org/programs"}]},{"text":""}]}]

title: Brand-new service presents the ultimate list of all-plant eateries delivering during Coronavirus lockdown
content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Visit them at "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.sayplants.com/","children":[{"text":"https://www.sayplants.com/"}]},{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":""},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.sayplants.com/","children":[{"text":""}]},{"text":"London-based duo cook up a Tripadvisor alternative for plant-based restaurants, looking to support independent businesses struggling through the lockdown."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"SayPlants is a brand-new online service that presents the ultimate guide to plant-based restaurants. The site helps hungry punters find incredible restaurant options nearby, using data to filter by location, budget, occasion, taste and more. They intend to inspire users with accurate, curated information on the most delicious plant-based restaurants, rather than alternative crowdsourced sites which can over-emphasise cynical and sometimes inaccurate restaurant reviews. Currently they exclusively cover London but have plans for UK-wide and international expansion."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Coronavirus has devastated the restaurant sector, especially SMEs. These independent businesses are responsible for the majority of UK employment and yet are the hardest-hit by unpredictable cash flow during lockdown - especially once the furlough scheme winds down. SayPlants aims to drive traffic to restaurants that are still delivering, and to promote attention for independent restaurants that reopen as lockdown is eased."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"People sitting at home are spending more money on takeaways once they tire of home cooking, but until now there was no single place to see all the plant-based delivery options nearby. SayPlants aims to inspire plant-based punters with convenience and choice. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"In the last few years, restaurants of all stripes have added outstanding all-plant options to their menus. SayPlants are keen to make eating plants more convenient than ever, whether you’re vegan, veggie, flexitarian or a steak lover. Everyone is invited."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Visit at "},{"type":"link","url":"https://www.sayplants.com/","children":[{"text":"https://www.sayplants.com/"}]},{"text":""}]}]

author: Sam

title: Researchers find that 1,000 metric tons of Microplastics fall on 11 protected areas in the US annually, equivalent to over 120 million plastic water bottles
content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Plastic Rain Is the New Acid Rain"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"These are unspoiled lands, collectively a great American conservation story. Yet an invisible menace is actually blowing through the air and falling via raindrops: Microplastic particles, tiny chunks (by definition, less than 5 millimeters long) of fragmented plastic bottles and microfibers that fray from clothes, all pollutants that get caught up in Earth’s atmospheric systems and deposited in the wilderness."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Writing today in the journal Science, researchers report a startling discovery: After collecting rainwater and air samples for 14 months, they calculated that over 1,000 metric tons of microplastic particles fall into 11 protected areas in the western US each year. That’s the equivalent of over 120 million plastic water bottles. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"It further confirms an increasingly hellish scenario: Microplastics are blowing all over the world, landing in supposedly pure habitats, like the Arctic and the remote French Pyrenees. They’re flowing into the oceans via wastewater and tainting deep-sea ecosystems, and they’re even ejecting out of the water and blowing onto land in sea breezes."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"This new research comes with another troubling surprise: 30 percent of the sample particles were microbeads, tiny synthetic spheres that the United States banned from beauty products in 2015. The microbeads in the samples, though, were generally smaller than the ones you’d find in those products."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Scientists have been trying to figure out what happens to the world’s plastic pollution, nearly all of which seems to “disappear” in the environment. But studies like this one are showing that the stuff never truly goes away, it just gets shredded into smaller bits that disperse all over the world, perhaps spending many years cycling through different systems—air, land, and sea."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"There’s still much that science has to learn about this microplastic cycle, but this much is clear: There’ll be no putting the plastic back in the bottle."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":""}]}]

title: BP predicts oil's demising value
content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"BP predicts falling demand for oil, leading to a $17.5 bn reduction in the value of their assets. Coronavirus and its economic effects has triggered the accounting change, but the move is contextualised by previous statements from the oil giant that they are taking the net zero target seriously and will be propelling their move into cleaner energy. author: Esmé Audland

title: "Finding Trails" - a theater+trails project
content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Why do people seek out trails? What is our relationship to wild places, and to ourselves in these wild places? Do you forge your own trail or follow someone else's?"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Penguin Productions, a community-based theater is Seattle, WA, commissioned 4 local award-winning playwrights to explore the joys (and discomforts!) of moving down trails, and the feeling of being both small and large in majestic spaces. By celebrating public lands through theater and connecting theater to public lands, we build a more resilient and joyful citizenry. By commissioning plays that speak specifically to the complex emotions we experience on trails, and the roles trails, wild spaces, and public lands play in our lives, we hope to help develop a richer theatrical vocabulary that can articulate the importance, relevance, and threat to these spaces. By centering diverse stories, centering human stories within the landscape, we center ourselves in the natural world and create stronger relationships and dialogues that will help us work towards positive solutions in the face of complex threats.  "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"​A representative from the Washington Trails Association also joined us with resources on how to find your next adventure. KNKX, a local NPR affiliate, did a nice piece that aired on Morning Edition. You can listen here - ​https://www.knkx.org/post/finding-trails-festival-brings-northwests-love-outdoors-theater-together"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The project pivoted to Zoom, and the event is available for streaming at "},{"type":"link","url":"http://penguinproductionsseattle.org/findingtrails.html","children":[{"text":"http://penguinproductionsseattle.org/findingtrails.html"}]},{"text":""}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Mi Cielo, by Sofia Raquel Sanchez. Directed by Rachel Delmar"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Route Finding, by Pamela Hobart Carter. Directed by Agastya Kohli"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The Light at the End, by Maggie Lee. Directed by Anna Ly"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Almighty God of Lake and Tree, by Frank Garland. Directed by David Gassner​"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Produced with support from the Seattle Office of Arts and Culture"}]}]

title: Carbon Choices - a book on the common-sense solutions to our climate and wildlife crises.
content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Coming from Scotland, home of the world’s 2021 climate conference, Carbon Choices tells the"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"greatest story on planet Earth. How one group of sociable animals came to emit 40 billion tonnes"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"(40,000,000,000) of an invisible gas each year, unwittingly changing the chemistry of the atmosphere"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"and the oceans, and steadily destroying the life support systems that humans and wildlife depend"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"on. It takes a fresh perspective on how the excessive consumption by wealthier people has"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"unwittingly driven us into climate and wildlife crises and considers the psychology that drives us to"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"buy more ‘stuff’ and whether this makes us happier."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Carbon Choices identifies ten building blocks that will enable us to build a more sustainable future;"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"and five common-sense principles to guide us in the decisions that we make."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"By applying these principles to our daily lives – our diets, homes, travel, shopping and leisure"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"activities - we can begin to reverse the damage that humans are causing, improve our society, make"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"us healthier, happier and lead more fulfilled lives."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"The book concludes with a call to action and a checklist for business and individuals to persuade"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"governments to set the regulatory framework that business needs to offer consumers better Carbon"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Choices."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"5 common sense principles:"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"1. Be fair across current and future generations"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"2. Price carbon pollution "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"3. Consume carefully, travel wisely"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"4. Embrace efficiency, avoid waste"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"5. Nurture nature"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"To be published September 2020.  www.carbonchoices.uk"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Please join me on my journey:  twitter: @carbonchoicesuk   www.facebook/carbonchoices"}]}]

title: Kajkao are making sustainable materials from agricultural waste
content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Only 50% of a cocoa pod is used to make chocolate; the rest usually goes to waste. Kajkao, an Italian-Ecuadorean team of designers, are changing this. They’re developing brilliant biodegradable materials from the waste generated by cocoa crops. title: Project Broadway are reducing London's carbon footprint one high street at a time
content: [{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"Broadway Market is a very popular site in London, and is taking steps to become more sustainable. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"text":"'We will show the world how a community in a city can significantly reduce its carbon footprint and halve its waste in a year. We will implement sustainable practices in each business, by completing a Carbon Account at the beginning of the project to identify where the largest emitting practices are. After analysing these figures we will create new and easily adaptable changes into the supply chains, practices and ethos.' - their site.
